title: Malaysia's Queen Azizah says Lee Kuan Yew loved her sambal belacan
text:
Malaysia's Queen Azizah said that the late Lee Kuan Yew (pictured) liked her sambal belacan (shrimp chilli paste, pictured) so much that he wrote to her asking her to send over more of the "delicious" condiment.

SINGAPORE — Malaysia’s queen, Tunku Azizah, says that the late Singapore statesman, Lee Kuan Yew, loved the sambal belacan (shrimp chilli paste) that she made, and that she supplied the spicy condiment to the Lee family on his request.

In fact, according to what appears to be a letter from the former prime minister to the queen that she shared on social media, Lee wrote that her belacan was “the best chilli belacan” that his family had tasted.

In the letter dated 23 July 2009, Lee wrote:

Dear Tengku Puan Tunku Azizah The six packets of belacan you gave me were delicious. I shared them with my two sons. They have all been consumed. It is the best chilli belacan we have tasted. Can my family have a few more? Sorry to trouble you over this. It makes so many dishes taste better. Yours sincerely,

Lee Kuan Yew





Tunku Azizah Aminah Maimunah first posted a photo of the letter on her Instagram (@airtangan_tunkuazizah) back in May 2018; she reposted it again on Twitter (@cheminahsayang) on Friday (25 Oct).

In her half-cheeky Twitter post, Tunku Azizah wrote in Malay, “I have wanted to share this with the people of Malaysia for a long time. I used to be the official sambal belacan supplier to the PM of Singapore, Dato Lee Kuan Yew... and now supply to his son, PM Lee, too!”

In her older Instagram post, Azizah had said of Lee’s letter, “This is such an important letter to me... All because of sambal belacan… I was deeply touched.”

Lee Kuan Yew and his family, who are Peranakan, would be quintessentially Peranakan in their love for sambal belacan, which features heavily in their Malay-influenced cuisine.

Azizah is queen to King Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah, who is also the Sultan of the state of Pahang and was crowned as Malaysia’s monarch in January this year. The Sultans of Malaysia rotate the position of king among themselves every five years.

Azizah is also the sister of the current Johor Sultan, Ibrahim ibni Almarhum Sultan Iskandar.

Here’s a closer look at the sambal belacan made by the queen. Doesn’t it look really sedap and spicy?

Sambal belacan made by Malaysian Queen Azizah, in a photo posted on her Instagram. More

The current Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew’s son, Lee Hsien Loong, is apparently also a big fan of Tunku Azizah’s cooking. Azizah shared what appears to be another letter by the younger Lee, dated September 2018, in which he expresses delight at receiving her cookbooks as gifts and promised that he and his wife, Ho Ching, would try out her recipes at home. He also sent Azizah a cookbook containing Peranakan recipes by his grandmother, Lee Chin Koon.





This is perhaps one good way to cement friendly diplomatic relations: through the sharing of delicious food among the officials of neighbouring countries!
description: The late Lee Kuan Yew's family, including current Singapore prime minister Lee Hsien Loong, apparently loves Queen Azizah's cooking.
